title: 103_s493
content: The "Hospital Cooperative Agreement Act" aims to promote collaboration among hospitals to reduce costs and enhance efficiency in healthcare delivery by avoiding unnecessary duplication of expensive medical services and equipment. Additionally, it introduces a Hospital Technology and Services Sharing Demonstration Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program to award grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology. The program aims to reduce costs, increase access to care, and improve quality of care. Eligible applicants must collaborate with two or more hospitals. The program aims to reduce costs, increase access to care, and improve quality of care through voluntary cooperative agreements between hospitals. Eligible applicants must be hospitals willing to collaborate with others. The program encourages hospitals to enter into voluntary cooperative agreements for sharing medical technology or services with other hospitals in the state or region. The cooperative agreement involves activities and considerations for hospitals sharing medical technology or services, with evaluation guidelines developed by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research. The Secretary will evaluate applications based on the guidelines. The Secretary, in consultation with the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, will evaluate applications submitted under paragraph (1) to determine grant awards based on developed guidelines. The Secretary will evaluate cooperative agreements in grant applications based on guidelines to enhance hospital care quality, preserve facilities, improve cost-effectiveness, and enhance technology services utilization. The grant awarded under this section aims to facilitate collaboration among hospitals to improve cost-effectiveness, efficient utilization of resources, and avoid duplication. Amounts provided cannot be used to purchase facilities or capital equipment. The grant awarded under this section is to facilitate collaboration among hospitals. Amounts provided cannot be used to purchase facilities or capital equipment, but can be used for expenses related to specialized personnel, administrative services, support services, and instructional programs. At least three grants must demonstrate cooperative agreements in rural areas. Not less than three grants awarded under this section must show how cooperative agreements can improve access to or quality of care in rural areas located outside of metropolitan statistical areas. The term 'rural areas' in this section refers to areas outside of metropolitan statistical areas. Cooperative agreements under this section involve sharing medical technology and services among participating hospitals, including drugs, devices, and medical procedures. The term 'medical technology' in this section includes drugs, devices, and medical procedures. Eligible services for sharing must have high capital or operating costs. The demonstration program established under this section allows for shared ownership of services with high capital or operating costs, aiming to avoid excess capacity in the community. The program, including mobile clinic services, will run for 5 years. The demonstration program allows for shared ownership of services to avoid excess capacity in the community. It includes mobile clinic services and will run for 5 years. A report will be submitted to Congress after 5 years to assess the program's impact on healthcare costs and access to medical services. Congress will receive a report on cooperative agreements aimed at reducing healthcare costs, increasing access to medical services, and improving healthcare quality. The report will also include recommendations for future programs. Additionally, it is stated that hospitals can enter into these agreements without violating antitrust laws. Hospitals can enter into cooperative agreements without violating antitrust laws, as stated in the Act. The Sherman Act, the Federal Trade Commission Act, and the Clayton Act are key laws that address unlawful restraints and monopolies in commerce. The Clayton Act, along with State antitrust laws, prohibits unlawful restraints and monopolies. Appropriations are authorized for enforcement from 1994 to 1998.
